pullRequest.body:
We abstract out the matroid property of 'having a well-defined `Cardinality`-valued rank function' as a typeclass `Matroid.CardinalRank`, and use it to  define a rank function `Matroid.cardRk` and prove basic properties. The fact that `Finitary` matroids have such a rank function is now provided as an instance. 

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

-->

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Thanks for the PRs!

I'm not sure we need/should emphasize Cardinal in the name, since it seems to be the default, it's the Nat-valued version that usually come with an adjective, e.g. [Module.finrank](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Dimension/Finrank.html#Module.finrank), [Field.finSepDegree](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/SeparableDegree.html#Field.finSepDegree), [Set.ncard](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Card.html#Set.ncard) (there's no `Set.card` though). So maybe we can call these `Matroid.HasRank`, `Matroid.rank`, `Matroid.setRank` (or `set.matroidRank`??), `hasRank_of_finitary`, `rank_inter_add_rank_union_le`.

Cardinal values are definitely not the default in the context of matroid theory. 

The 'default' rank function is `ENat`-valued, because this is the one that's well-defined for all matroids rather than special subclasses like finitary matroids, and it arises naturally when axiomatising infinite matroids. Note that `ENat` goes hand in hand with `Set.encard`. 

I have actually never seen a cardinal-valued rank function in the literature - it was an interesting surprise to see the demand for one here!

If you define Cardinal-valued `rank` to be the supremum over bases then it's also well-defined. And you can still get the ENat-valued rank using [Cardinal.toENat](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/ENat.html#Cardinal.toENat). I'm a bit surprised that cardinal-valued ranks don't appear in the matroid literature, because it's a standard result in algebra textbooks that all bases of a vector space over a field have the same cardinality, so the dimension is well-defined (and this example of (finitary) matroid is even more famous than the AlgebraicIndependent one). As for trdeg, I don't think people care much about field extensions with infinite trdeg, but it's just nice to be able to show the result too holds in the infinite case.

Even if you define it as a supremum, the cardinal rank function is unhelpful for general infinite matroids. It's fine to define `ENat` rank in terms of cardinal rank, but calling the latter `rank` would consign the natural default language to a niche setting. 

Any infinite rank function is too coarse to distinguish different infinite matroids. But when one does make an effort to axiomatize infinite matroids in terms of a rank-like function, the function that ends up working (a form of 'relative rank') is `ENat`-valued, and allowing it to take cardinal values gains nothing. 

The applications in algebraic geometry are very nice to see! But they are just an application, and I think it would be a mistake to use them to prescribe terminology.

```suggestion
(see the module docstring of `Mathlib.Data.Matroid.Basic`).
```
The name is Higgs, so either Higgs' or Higgs's? (I never knows which is more correct; it seems people use both when referring to a single Higgs.)
Thanks!
Can you use `wlog ... generalizing α` here? Maybe generalizing `B B' N` is enough, since restriction doesn't change α.
I don't think so, because `CardinalRank` requires a statement about `Basis` rather than `Base`.
Maybe I'm missing something though.
Oh you're right, I missed the distinction between Basis and Base.
Does it make more sense to define this as the ~~maximum (or minimum)~~ supremum (or infimum)? For the current definition, the docstring should probably say "a random base". (same for `cardRk`)

Is there mathematical significance to taking a min/maximum in the case where bases can have different cardinalities? This seems like such a pathological situation to me (it requires exotic set-theoretic assumptions like Martin's axiom to be possible) that I thought it wasn't worth the hassle of a slightly more complicated definition.

I'd expect analogues of [rank_quotient_add_rank_le](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Dimension/Constructions.html#rank_quotient_add_rank_le) wouldn't hold if the rank isn't defined to be the supremum but random. (I am not sure how to state the analogue (if any exists) in matroid theory though.) (Also worth noting that Module.rank is defined to be the supremum over linearly independent sets rather than the [maximal independent](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/LinearIndependent.html#LinearIndependent.Maximal) ones.)

Yes, such analogues might fail. 

But my point is more that one has no business talking about cardinal rank in the first place if it's not well-behaved. For example, it is consistent with ZFC that there are matroids having both a countable basis and an uncountable basis. What I take away from this is less 'the definition needs to be fixed', and more that 'talking about cardinalities of bases in general matroids is folly'.

Is there a concrete situation you're referring to where it is productive to be thinking about matroid basis cardinalities, even when they aren't stable?

I think it makes more sense to swap the two sides of the identities, in conformity with [Basis.mk_eq_rank''](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Dimension/StrongRankCondition.html#Basis.mk_eq_rank'') etc. Then these could potentially be simp lemmas. (The current direction can't be because there can be multiple RHS for the same LHS.)
I think I disagree (conceptually, 'rank' is more complicated than 'size'). And it feels like it's the wrong direction for simplification in most cases, as well.

~~`rank` is defined to be the size of a random base, right? So size is more fundamental than `rank`. And~~ Sorry, this is exactly what you're saying. `rank` is indeed more complicated than size. However, size -> rank is conceptually the "normalizing" direction, as it turns potentially different sizes into the same size. Simp lemmas have to possess the normalizing/confluent property.
I see your point, and that had never occured to me. I will change them.

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/Matroid/Rank/Cardinal): Cardinality-valued rank function
